name: The Anti-Pitch
description: Kellen Casebeer's objection-prevention approach. Address their likely objection BEFORE they think it. Disarm skepticism by acknowledging what they're probably thinking.
guidelines: Think: 'What will they think when they see this email?'
Address their objection before they have to say it
Be honest about the objection, then offer new framing
Give genuine permission to ignore if it doesn't fit

examples.context: Outreach tool vendor reaching out to someone who gets many pitches
examples.subject: you have 5 already
examples.body:
Sarah - I know you probably have 3-5 sales engagement tools in your stack. Last thing you need is another SDR tool email.

So I won't pitch features.

But are your reps actually using all of them? Most sales leaders I talk to have tool bloat and reps who bypass the 'official' tools.

If consolidating your stack is on your radar, might be worth a chat. Either way, no hard feelings.
examples.whyItWorks: Names their exact objection, pivots to real problem, gives genuine permission to ignore

examples.context: Marketing agency reaching out during tough economic times
examples.subject: probably not right time
examples.body:
Marcus - let me guess: marketing budgets are frozen and the last thing you need is an agency pitch.

Totally get it.

But companies investing in content right now are getting 2-3x more organic traffic share because competitors stopped.

If you're one of those contrarian marketers, we should talk. If not, I'll check back in Q3.
examples.whyItWorks: Acknowledges budget reality, offers contrarian reframe

examples.context: Consultant reaching out to someone who handles things in-house
examples.subject: probably don't need help
examples.body:
Jennifer - you probably have a solid HR team and don't need a consultant telling you how to do your job.

Fair. I'll make this quick.

We specialize in the one thing internal teams don't have time for: building career ladders and leveling frameworks from scratch.

If that's been on your Q2 list for three quarters now, might be worth outsourcing the grunt work.
examples.whyItWorks: Acknowledges their competence, narrows to one specific pain point

promptTemplate:
You are writing a cold email using 'The Anti-Pitch' approach.

CORE PRINCIPLE: Address their likely objection BEFORE they think it.

STRUCTURE:
1. ACKNOWLEDGE: Name their likely objection upfront
2. VALIDATE: Show you understand why they'd think that
3. REFRAME: Offer a new angle to consider
4. PERMISSION: Give them genuine permission to ignore

RULES:
- Be honest and self-aware
- Give them a real 'out' if it's not relevant
- Keep under 100 words
- Subject line: 1-4 words
